I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  After  the  successful  completion  of  the  Water  Resources  Management  and  Land 
Improvement Project (WRMLIP) in 2006, the Government of Kazakhstan requested1 the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) to provide technical assistance (TA) for preparing the Second Water 
Resources Management and Land Improvement Project, to increase agricultural productivity and 
profitability in Makhtaaral raion in Southern Kazakhstan oblast. The proposed project received 
concept clearance in October 2007.  
 
2.  A reconnaissance mission from ADB visited Kazakhstan from 19 to 28 June 2007. On the 
basis of the results of that mission, a memorandum of understanding outlining the basic elements 
of  the  proposed  TA,  including  outputs,  methodology,  cost  and  financing,  implementation 
arrangements, and government contribution, was signed. A fact-finding mission visited Astana, 
Kazakhstan, from 4 to 6 November 2007 to clarify (i) the required documentation for expertise2 to 
be  submitted  to  the  Government  before  it  would  approve  funding,  (ii)  the  steps  in  the 
Government’s budgeting and approval process, and (iii) Government’s commitment to financing 
the ensuing project. The fact-finding mission led to the signing of a second memorandum of 
understanding clarifying the area coverage of the TA and its implementing arrangements, and 
reiterating the basic elements of the proposed technical assistance.3 The Government confirmed 
its request for ADB technical assistance for the preparation of an 80,000 hectare (ha) project in 
Makhtaaral raion in South Kazakhstan oblast.  
II.  ISSUES 
A.  Policy Context 
3.  The Government, giving high priority to the processing of agricultural products, has made 
major  investments  in  cotton  processing  and  the  associated  textile  industry.  However,  since 
industrial crops like cotton fully depend on irrigation, agricultural productivity is constrained by 
dilapidated  irrigation  and  drainage  (I&D)  systems,  particularly  in  the  southern  areas,  where 
agriculture could otherwise be highly profitable. 
 
4.  Reforms in the agriculture sector include the restructuring of state and collective farms and 
the distribution of land and farm assets to former members. Private farms have emerged. Small 
“peasant” farms, comprising a few households, crop over 40% of agricultural land, and larger 
entities (limited companies and cooperatives) cover the balance. Small household plots are an 
important source of production for rural households. But the yields of major crops and livestock 
products are low by international standards because of incomplete farm restructuring, lack of 
access to machinery, inadequate advisory services, insufficient access to affordable credit, and 
the high costs of transportation over the long distances to markets. 
 
5.  A recent agricultural policy assessment4 emphasized the need for sustainability, efficient 
water management, and a gradual increase in fees to cover real service delivery costs. To 
achieve these, (i) I&D systems would have to be rehabilitated and modernized; (ii) public and 
private institutions involved in irrigation, including water users organizations5 (WUOs), would have

to strengthen their capacity; (iii) irrigation service fees would have to be raised to levels that would 
allow the long-term management and operation and maintenance (O&M) of irrigation systems; 
and (iv) the management of limited water resources would have to improve. 
 
6.  The Government passed two important laws in 2003: (i) the Water Code; and (ii) the Law 
on Rural and Consumer Cooperatives of Water Users, which was amended in 2006. Armed with 
this  legislation,  and  in  view  of  the  importance  of  agriculture  to  the  national  economy  and 
particularly to the rural population, the Government has embarked on a program to improve the 
efficiency of water use in agriculture and reduce the demand on scarce surface water resources. 
The strategy is to accelerate the improvement of over a million hectares of irrigated land. A variety 
of  mechanisms  are  envisaged—instituting  water  pricing,  rehabilitating  and  modernizing  I&D 
infrastructure, establishing water control mechanisms, introducing on-farm water management 
practices, improving agricultural practices, and strengthening the capacity of institutions including 
users organizations. The policy reforms contained in this legislation will form the core of the 
proposed project. The principal aims will be to establish sustainable management and O&M of 
irrigation and drainage systems, to transfer the management of water use and water infrastructure 
to users, and to recover the cost of water delivery.  
B.  Subsector Issues 
7.  About 70% of the irrigated lands in the country (about 2.4 million ha) are in southern 
Kazakhstan. Population density in the southern oblasts is also among the highest in the country. 
Derelict irrigation and drainage systems have reduced the cultivated area since 1991: only about 
55% of the developed area (about 1.3 million ha out of 2.4 million ha) is now under irrigation.  
 
8.  Deterioration  of  Irrigation  and  Drainage  Systems.  Inadequate maintenance over a 
number of years has left irrigation canals, drains, and structures, as well as access roads and 
bridges, in extremely poor condition. Many systems have been partially or completely destroyed, 
and even those that are still functioning have poorly maintained structures and lack gates, rising 
spindles, and other related mechanical and electrical equipment. These problems extend to the 
drainage systems, many of which have had very limited maintenance and do not function well. 
Like the canals, most drains are blocked with reeds, weeds, and grasses, and certain sections 
have silted up. Vertical drainage wells are mostly out of order. As a result, the water table has 
risen close to ground level and soil salinity has increased. 
 
9.  The Need for Water User Organizations. The privatization of irrigated state farms in 
South Kazakhstan oblast without the restructuring of the institutional mechanisms for O&M led to 
a complete breakdown of the drainage systems. The WUOs that are to manage the irrigation and 
drainage systems have yet to be firmly established and to operate, except in recently rehabilitated 
areas.  
 
10.  Land Degradation and Declining Productivity. Water use efficiency is very low and 
drainage is also poor, leading to increasing waterlogging and soil salinization. If the water table is 
not controlled through adequate drainage channels and pumping wells, more land will gradually 
fall out of production. As it is, the irrigated lands that are still being cultivated have declined in 
overall productivity (i.e., crop yields). Better water management to improve water use efficiency 
will reduce land degradation. However, farmers need to learn better agronomic practices such as 
crop rotation, crop diversification, and crop husbandry to boost agricultural productivity.

3 
C.  Lessons Learned 
11.  Over the past decade, ADB has gained considerable experience in irrigation and drainage 
improvements in the region, not only in Kazakhstan but also in neighboring countries like the 
Kyrgyz Republic, Tajikistan, and Uzbekistan. The ADB-funded WRMLIP was designed to support 
the Government’s policy of privatizing agricultural farms by facilitating the transfer of irrigation and 
drainage  systems  management  to  private  farmers,  and  increasing  crop  productivity  by 
rehabilitating infrastructure and improving the condition of land in the project area. The project, 
implemented  in  1998–2006  on  39,259 ha  of  irrigated  land,  succeeded  in  rehabilitating  I&D 
networks and transferring their management and ownership to WUOs. It was well received by 
beneficiaries—some 5,000 farm households—and raised expectations for long-awaited follow-on 
improvements in still unimproved areas in the raion.  
 
12.   An  important  lesson  from  previous  experience  is  that  a  project  should  establish 
organizational and financial arrangements to sustain the infrastructure after rehabilitation. O&M, 
as well as training, costs should be provided for in WUOs’ operating and equipment budgets. 
Moreover, rehabilitation should not be treated in isolation, and wider support for agricultural 
development should be considered an integral element of any future project.   
 
13.  Specific land and water management improvements (e.g., deep ripping, land leveling) are 
considered essential to achieving the full benefit of project interventions. However, in some 
projects these measures are neglected or poorly implemented. Future projects should include 
proper implementation mechanisms to ensure that specific measures are not neglected. With 
cotton so predominant in the Makhtaaral area, there is an urgent need for agricultural extension 
advice  on  crop  rotation,  diversification,  crop  husbandry,  and  use  of  agrochemicals.  Future 
projects should include agricultural advisory support to maximize potential benefits.  
 
14.  Cost recovery details should be well understood by the project beneficiaries at the time 
alternative design options are discussed. Affordability, as well as the cost of sustainable O&M of 
the infrastructure, should be considered. Beneficiaries should be fully aware of repayment details 
before agreeing on preferred rehabilitation measures. 
 
15.  In  the  WRMLIP,  rehabilitation  works  were  undertaken  through  two  large  civil  works 
contracts with international contractors. This arrangement offered the advantage of securing the 
services of qualified contractors with the resources to mobilize modern equipment, while also 
allowing smaller works to be implemented through local subcontractors. This same approach, if 
used in future projects will make it possible to deploy modern equipment and transfer skills. 
However, there must be safeguards to ensure that the contractors adhere to design specifications, 
construct works of the specified quality, and complete their contracted tasks efficiently. Stringent 
oversight of construction should be an integral part of any future project. 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
16.  The impact of the proposed project will be sustained improvement in rural livelihood 
through improved productivity of agricultural land.

B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
18.  The TA will adopt a participatory approach and will hold broad consultations with farmers, 
WUOs, local governments,6 and oblast agencies, especially local offices of the Committee for 
Water Resources (CWR).7 Participatory workshops will be held at the raion level, to review the 
state  of  agriculture,  assess  alternative  design  approaches,  and  discuss  the  findings  and 
recommendations of the consultants. More intensive workshops and focus groups meetings will 
be held with farmers, WUOs, private sector, and aid-financed projects, to engender ownership of, 
and agreement on, the detailed design and implementation arrangements. 
 
19.  The TA will proceed from the assessment phase through project design to a study of the 
project’s engineering, economic, social, and environment feasibility, and finally to the preparation 
of  documentation  for  the  consideration  of  the  Government  and  ADB  Management.  In  the 
assessment phase, economic, social, and institutional aspects of Makhtaaral raion—particularly 
its irrigated agriculture subsector, its I&D systems, and agronomic conditions of irrigated lands—
will be assessed. The capacity and governance of relevant institutions will also be evaluated.  
 
20.  In the project design phase, the project area will be defined and proposed interventions 
identified, on the basis of the assessments and lessons learned in previous projects, especially 
the  recently  completed  ADB  WRMLIP.  The  intent  is  to  (i) support  and  strengthen  WUOs, 
(ii) rehabilitate and improve I&D systems, and (iii) achieve sustainable improvements in irrigated 
agricultural productivity.  A  preliminary  design and  monitoring  framework  outlining  the  project 
impact, outcomes, outputs, and components will be prepared.  
 
21.  During the feasibility study phase, the following will be prepared: (i) environmental and 
social assessments; (ii) engineering surveys and feasibility-level designs, with cost estimates for 
civil works, design services, goods, and training; (iii) detailed specifications of interventions for 
sustainable support to WUOs, with cost estimates for services, goods, operating costs, and 
training; (iv) proposals to strengthen the management and O&M of WUO-owned infrastructure; (v) 
detailed specifications of sustainable improvements in irrigated agricultural productivity, including 
cost estimates for services, goods, operating costs, and training; (vi) proposals for design and 
construction  supervision  services,  including  terms  of  reference;  (vii)  project  management 
arrangements,  including  monitoring  and  evaluation procedures;  (viii)  the  final  design  and 
monitoring framework; (ix) final project cost estimates; and (x) economic and financial analyses to 
estimate the rates of return on investment. The results of the feasibility study phase will be a basis 
for the documentation of the requirements for construction, ecological management, agriculture, 
and economic expertise, to be submitted to the relevant Kazakhstan government agencies, as a 
prerequisite for government funding, and for project appraisal.  
C.  Cost and Financing 
22.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $749,000. ADB will finance $600,000 on a grant 
basis from its TA funding program. The Government will provide $149,000 equivalent through 
in-kind  contributions  of  office  accommodation,  data  compilation,  logistical  support,  and 
counterpart staff. Detailed cost estimates and financing are in Appendix 3. The Government has 
been informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project.

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
23.  The Executing Agency for the TA will be the CWR. A project steering committee, under 
the CWR chairman and with representatives from the Ministry of Agriculture, the Ministry of 
Economy and Budget Planning, other relevant government agencies, and the oblast and raion 
governments, will be established. The committee will meet regularly to review the proposed 
project  design  and  the  progress  of  the  TA.  ADB  staff  will  participate  in  steering  committee 
meetings and, with the committee members and TA consultants, in workshops and tripartite 
meetings at TA inception, during the midterm review, and during the review of the draft final report. 
CWR will nominate a working group of senior staff members to guide the development of the 
project design by the TA consultants. The consulting team will be based in the field, and will hold 
office in Zhetysai (the raion center) and Shymkent (the oblast center). 
 
24.  It is proposed that the TA be undertaken over 6 months, from February 2008 to July 2008. 
About 58 person-months of consulting services (18 international and 40 national) will be required. 
The proposed international experts will include a team leader/economist, an institutional and 
water  users  association  development  specialist,  an  irrigation  and  drainage  engineer,  a  land 
improvement specialist, an environment specialist, a social development specialist, and financial 
and economic analyst. The proposed national experts will include a deputy team leader/irrigation 
and drainage engineer, an economist, an institutional specialist, an agronomist, a sustainable 
land management specialist, a rural sociologist, and an environment specialist, as well as other 
specialists as needed. Outline terms of reference for the consultants are presented in Appendix 4. 
The  consultants  will  be  hired  as  individuals  according  to  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). All procurement under the Project will be 
carried out in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to 
time). An initial poverty and social analysis has been prepared (Appendix 2).  
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION  
25.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of Kazakhstan for preparing the Second Water Resources Management and Land 
Improvement Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

I.  POVERTY ISSUES 
A.  Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy 
A general framework for the project is provided by the 2003 Poverty Partnership Agreement, which includes a midterm 
strategy (until 2010) that  states: 
“Creation of market-competitive farming and agriculture activities and diversification of the rural economy in the agriculture and 
non-agriculture sectors…will encompass (a) improving farm and rural enterprise access to domestic and international market; 
(b) rural infrastructure development; (c) upgrading farm technologies, research and extension services with greater private 
sector involvement; (d) deepening sector reforms at local levels; and (e) capacity building for local and national executives, 
and producers’ and community-based associations involved in agriculture and rural development.” 
 
More recently, the Government has made the development of the agriculture sector a priority as a source of economic 
development and diversification.

C.  Poverty Analysis 
 
The technical assistance (TA) will require poverty analysis that is disaggregated by gender. The TA will examine poverty 
incidence using existing data sources, supplemented with a social survey of potential beneficiaries. Both income and non-
income poverty indices will be determined. Particular attention in the stakeholder analysis will be given to profiling, for each 
type of service, the (i) beneficiaries, (ii) adversely affected peoples, and (iii) socioeconomic groups that will not be affected. 
Data collected will include, where possible, (i) gender-disaggregated demographic, economic, and social data; (ii) the 
incidence of poverty and vulnerable groups; (iii) ability and willingness to pay for cost recovery; and (iv) any adverse impact 
anticipated from the project. 
 
The project preparatory TA (PPTA) poverty analysis will focus on (i) analyzing how access to services, markets, and asset 
resources (especially land and credit) is differentiated between the poor and the nonpoor; (ii) identifying ways of improving the 
contribution of the project to reducing poverty and inequality; and (iii) assessing whether vulnerable groups will be better off or 
worse off as a result of the project, and the need for mitigating measures. The analysis will be carried out in accordance with 
ADB’s Poverty Handbook (2006) and Social Analysis Handbook (2007). The poverty analysis will also examine the links 
between poverty and land degradation. 
 
II.  SOCIAL DEVELOPMENT ISSUES 
A. Initial Social Analysis 
Makhtaaral raion is predominantly a cotton-growing area and the farmers are relatively well off compared with farmers in other 
parts of Kazakhstan. The population is mostly of Kazakh origin. Incomes have improved in areas that were covered by the 
previous ADB Water Resources Management and Land Improvement Project.  
 
The potential beneficiaries of the proposed project will be the farmers on about 80,000 ha of irrigated lands that have not been 
rehabilitated. In these areas, water users associations are less well organized. The farmers will be organized into water user 
associations, which will be strengthened through capacity building. Farmers will also receive training in water management, 
sustainable land management, and farm management.  
 
B. Consultation and Participation 
A participatory approach will be at the core of the PPTA, for the purpose of (i) collecting data, and (ii) making collaborative 
decisions about project designs with key stakeholders. Participatory rural appraisal techniques will be used during the 
assessment and design phases.

relevant agencies at raion and oblast levels, especially local offices of CWR. Participatory workshops will be held at the raion 
level, to review the state of agriculture, assess alternative design approaches, and discuss the findings and recommendations 
of the consultants. More intensive workshops and focus groups meetings will be held with farmers, WUOs, the private sector, 
and government agencies implementing aid-financed projects to engender ownership of, and agreement on the detailed 
design and implementation arrangements.

C. Gender and Development 
As part of the social assessment, the consultant will undertake a gender analysis to determine gender inequality in access to 
assets, services, and decision making related to project interventions; assess the current gender division of labor; and identify 
ways to narrow the gender gaps and empower women. In addition, activities to promote more active participation by women 
in the project will be identified and incorporated into the project design.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
A.  Overview 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will proceed from the assessment phase through project 
design to the engineering, economic, social, and environmental feasibility study, and finally to 
the preparation of documentation for consideration by the Government and Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) Management.  
2.  In the assessment phase, economic, social, and institutional aspects of Makhtaaral 
raion—particularly its irrigated agriculture subsector, its irrigation and drainage (I&D) systems, 
and  the  agronomic  conditions  of  irrigated  lands—will  be  assessed.  The  capacity  and 
governance of relevant institutions will also be assessed.  
3.  In  the  project  design  phase,  the  results  of  these  assessments,  combined  with  an 
analysis of lessons learned in previous projects in the agriculture sector, especially the recently 
completed ADB Water Resources Management and Land Improvement Project, will help define 
the project area and identify a set of proposed interventions (i) to support and strengthen water 
user organizations (WUOs), (ii) to rehabilitate and improve I&D systems, and (iii) to achieve 
sustainable  improvements  in  irrigated  agricultural  productivity.  A  preliminary  design  and 
monitoring framework outlining the project impact, outcomes, outputs, and components will be 
prepared.  
4.  During the feasibility study phase, the following will be prepared: (i) environmental and 
social assessments; (ii) engineering surveys and feasibility-level designs with cost estimates for 
civil works, design services, goods, and training; (iii) detailed specifications of interventions for 
sustainable support to WUOs, including cost estimates for services, goods, operating costs, and 
training; (iv) proposals to strengthen the management and the operation and maintenance 
(O&M) of  WUO-owned infrastructure; (v) detailed specifications of interventions to achieve 
sustainable  improvements  in  irrigated  agricultural  productivity,  including  cost  estimates  for 
services,  goods,  operating  costs,  and  training;  (vi)  proposals  for  design  and  construction 
supervision  services,  including  outline  terms  of  reference;  (vii)  project  management 
arrangements,  including  monitoring  and  evaluation procedures;  (viii)  the  final    design  and 
monitoring framework; (ix) final project cost estimates; and (x) economic and financial analyses 
to estimate the rates of return on investment. 
5.  The  results  of  the  feasibility  study  phase  will  be  used  to  prepare  the  construction, 
ecological management, agriculture, and economic expertise, to be submitted to the relevant 
Kazakhstan government agencies, and for project appraisal.  
B.  Assessment 
6.  The consultants will adopt participatory approaches to ensure the involvement of all 
stakeholders,  from  national  to  community  levels,  in  project  identification  and  design.  The 
participation should be sufficient to ensure that the beneficiaries and the national and local 
agencies reach consensus on and commitment to the design and implementation arrangements 
and, where necessary, responsibility for operation.  
1.  Economic Assessment 
7.  A broad survey of South Kazakhstan oblast and a detailed review of Makhtaaral raion 
will be carried out by the consultants, on the basis of existing reports and project documents, 
and some farm-level rapid rural appraisal. The analysis of the current status of economic and

Appendix 4         13 
   
social  development  in  the  area  will  include  (i) the  progress  of  agriculture  reforms,  and 
constraints on their effective implementation; and (ii) the socioeconomic situation, highlighting 
economic and social issues affecting the rural population, particularly women and vulnerable 
groups, and the effects of farm restructuring, reduction of social services, and limited access to 
resources (including land) and infrastructure. 
2.  Social Assessment 
8.  The consultants will identify the beneficiaries and groups that would be affected by the 
pProject and make a social assessment of these groups according to ADB’s Handbook on 
Poverty and Social Analysis, Handbook for Integrating Poverty Impact in Economic Analysis of 
Projects, and Gender Checklist: Agriculture. They will conduct a socioeconomic survey to profile 
the beneficiaries, using gender-disaggregated demographic, economic, and social data, where 
possible (including poverty incidence, vulnerable groups, ability and willingness to pay for cost 
recovery, and any adverse impact anticipated from the project). A preliminary assessment will 
be carried out with respect to ADB’s Policy on Indigenous Peoples (1998) and Involuntary 
Resettlement Policy (1995). 
3.  Institutional Assessment 
9.  The  consultants  will  assess  institutional  aspects  related  to  irrigated  agriculture  and 
identify the main constraints as well as opportunities for strengthening. The assessment will 
cover (i) the roles, responsibilities, and capacity of local institutions1 supporting agriculture and 
delivering irrigation services, and opportunities for strengthening these agencies; (ii) the number, 
strength,  and  effectiveness  of  WUOs  and  other  agriculture-based  organizations,  and 
arrangements for supporting their development; (iii) private sector involvement in the agriculture 
sector,  particularly  in  rural  finance,  input  supply,  machine  leasing,  output  storage, 
agro-processing, and marketing, including the role of cooperatives and farmers’ associations; 
(iv) the role, approach, and activities of nongovernment organizations and the private sector in 
the area; and (v) formal and informal training of farmers. 
4.  Assessment of Irrigated Agriculture 
10.  The consultants will assess irrigated agriculture, particularly in Makhtaaral raion, and 
identify the main constraints and opportunities in the subsector. The assessment will cover 
(i) the ownership structure of farms and factors influencing the success of private farming; 
(ii) constraints on farm productivity and profitability (rapid rural appraisal and base data from the 
most recent agricultural census will help identify farm types, farm size, ownership, land, labor 
and capital availability, output, productivity, and net income, disaggregated by farm enterprise 
and, where applicable, by gender); (iii) the market potential of the region, the competitiveness of 
its products, the potential for increased competitiveness, and constraints on achieving this 
competitiveness, including an analysis of the comparative advantage of the project area); and 
(iv) the availability and accessibility to farmers of input supplies, technology, finance, markets 
and marketing facilities and channels, extension and research, and transport and distribution 
networks. 
                                                 
1  Understood here to mean those at the oblast and raion levels.

14      Appendix 4 
 
5.  Assessment of Irrigation and Drainage Systems 
11.  The consultants will assess in detail the I&D systems in Makhtaaral raion, particularly 
those networks that were not rehabilitated under earlier projects. The assessment will cover: 
(i) the condition of the I&D networks, and water demand for anticipated cropping systems and 
leaching; (ii) rehabilitation and modernization needs and estimated costs, derived from surveys 
and preliminary designs; (iii) current water management arrangements and recommendations 
for  improvement;  (iv) existing  arrangements  and  available  resources  for  O&M  (financing, 
facilities, contractors); (v) existing legislation relating to WUOs; (vi)  the current status of the 
transfer of management of I&D infrastructure to water users; (vii) the capacity of WUOs to 
manage, operate, and maintain their systems, and recommendations for making this capacity 
sustainable;  (viii)  farmers’  capacity  (willingness  and  ability)  to  pay  service  fees  at  levels 
sufficient to sustain the I&D systems over time (including pumping for irrigation and drainage); 
and (ix) cost recovery mechanisms. 
6.  Agronomic Assessment 
12.  The consultants will (i) collect baseline information on the type of soils, topography, and 
land-use patterns; (ii) analyze water-use patterns (e.g., rain-fed crops, irrigated crops, drainage, 
surface and groundwater extraction); and (iii) examine existing field-crop production and soil 
management  practices.  They  will  review  existing  information  management  and  monitoring 
systems, including project-specific database systems, conduct spatial analysis, and produce 
maps of land-use patterns (e.g., the areal extent and distribution of land degradation, and areas 
vulnerable to land degradation).  
7.  Assessment of Capacity 
13.  The consultants will assess the capacity of the executing and implementing agencies 
and describe the organizational arrangements for project implementation, including coordination. 
The consultants will prepare project implementation schedules and procurement packages for 
civil works, equipment, and services according to ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as 
amended from time to time). They will also prepare terms of reference for the international and 
national consultants needed to support project implementation. 
8.  Assessment of Governance 
14.  The consultants will assess governance related to the project, according to the ADB 
guidelines.2 They will prepare a financial management assessment of the Executing Agency 
according to ADB’s Guidelines for Financial Management and Analysis of Projects, including an 
assessment of the financial accounting and management systems of the relevant executing and 
implementing agencies, especially CWR, and make recommendations regarding the accounting 
and management of project expenditures, contract management, and the flow of funds from the 
Government and ADB. 
C.  Project Design 
15.  On the basis of the preceding analysis, the consultants will review the experience and 
lessons  learned  from  past  projects,  in  particular  the  ADB-supported  Water  Resources 
Management  and  Land  Improvement  Project (WRMLIP)  and  the  World  Bank–supported 
                                                 
2   Guidelines  are  currently  being  developed.  The  consultants  should  contact  the  Capacity  Development  and 
Governance Division in ADB’s Regional and Sustainable Development Department for guidance.

Appendix 4         15 
   
Irrigation and Drainage Improvement Project, both in Kazakhstan, as well as the ADB-funded 
Agriculture Area Development Project in the Kyrgyz Republic. The consultants will assess 
alternative  approaches  to  project  design,  on  the  basis  of  a  detailed  problem  tree  and  a 
preliminary  assessment  of  the  options  identified.  Agreement  with  the  Government  will  be 
obtained on the geographical focus and broad scope, and potential links with existing activities 
of the Government, private sector institutions, and external funding agencies will be identified. 
After  assessing  the  project  design  alternatives,  the  consultants  will  prepare  a  design  and 
monitoring framework (outlining the project impact, outcomes, outputs, activities, and inputs, 
and including realistic performance indicators and targets, appropriate monitoring mechanisms, 
and key risks and assumptions) using ADB’s Guidelines for Preparing a Design and Monitoring 
Framework). This framework will be used as a participatory design tool for the project. A project 
performance monitoring system will be prepared to facilitate monitoring and evaluation. 
D.  Engineering Feasibility 
16.  The consultants will conduct engineering surveys and prepare feasibility-level designs 
with cost estimates for civil works, design services, goods, and training. The preliminary designs 
will  be  accompanied  with  estimates  of  the  type  and  scope  of  works  to  be  undertaken  to 
rehabilitate and modernize the I&D networks. In addition, the consultants will determine the TA 
needs and develop proposals for design and construction supervision services.  
E.  Economic and Financial Analyses 
17.  The consultants will prepare detailed project cost estimates—including categories of 
investment, operational costs, and interest during construction—using COSTAB software. Cost 
items will be separated into foreign exchange (including direct and indirect costs) and local 
costs and physical and price contingencies. The Government’s contribution will include duties 
and taxes, which should be identified separately. A financing plan indicating the contributions 
from  the  Government,  ADB,  the  private  sector,  beneficiaries,  and  any  cofinanciers  will  be 
prepared. 
F.  Expertise for Government Approval 
18.  As  required  by  the  Kazakhstan  Government,  the  consultants  will  provide  the 
Government with draft documentation for the necessary construction, ecological, agriculture, 
and economic expertise, for its approval.  
G.  Safeguards 
1.  Environment 
19.  The consultants will prepare an initial environmental examination (IEE) and summary 
IEE according to ADB’s Environment Policy (2002) and Environmental Assessment Guidelines 
(2003), and the Government’s environmental requirements. The IEE and summary IEE will 
identify all potential environmental impact and describe the mitigating measures, monitoring 
requirements,  budgetary  requirements,  and  institutional  arrangements.  If  an  environmental 
impact  assessment  (EIA)  is  required,  the  consultants  will  prepare  the  necessary  terms  of 
reference, the EIA, and the summary  EIA according to the requirements of ADB and the 
Government.

16      Appendix 4 
 
2.  Social Safeguards 
20.  The consultants will assess compliance with ADB’s Policy on Indigenous Peoples (1998) 
and Involuntary Resettlement Policy (1995). The assessment of involuntary resettlement (IR) 
safeguard issues will include the screening of all proposed components for any IR impact 
resulting from land acquisition, changes in land use, and restricted access to land, and the 
preparation of a resettlement plan, if required, according to ADB’s Involuntary Resettlement 
Policy. Similarly, the assessment will validate the impact of the project on indigenous peoples; 
any necessary documentation will conform to ADB’s Policy on Indigenous Peoples. 
H.  Reporting 
21.  The consultants will produce the following reports and attend the related meetings: 
(i)  Inception  report  (week  4),  with  the  work  plan  and  schedule  for  the  TA.  A 
tripartite review meeting will be held in week 5 to discuss the report. 
(ii)  Interim report (week 12), on progress made and including details of the project 
area, links with existing institutions, lessons from donor-supported projects, an 
assessment  of  constraints  and  opportunities  (using  a  problem  tree),  and 
alternative project designs. The report will provide a description of the project 
design with a detailed design and monitoring framework, component descriptions, 
and preliminary implementation arrangements, and identify key issues requiring 
resolution. A tripartite review meeting will be held in week 13 to discuss the 
report. 
(iii)  Draft final report (week 20), covering all aspects of the project described in the 
tasks above. A tripartite review meeting will be held in week 21 to discuss this 
draft report. 
(iv)  Final report (week 26), incorporating the revisions from the tripartite review and 
comments from stakeholders. 
22.  All reports will be produced in both English and Russian. Five copies of each report in 
English will be submitted to ADB, and two copies in English and five copies in Russian to the 
Government. In addition, key working papers will be submitted to the Government and ADB. 
I.  Consulting Requirements 
23.  It  is  proposed  that  the  TA  be  undertaken  over  6  months,  from  February  2008  to 
July 2008. It is estimated that 58 person-months of consulting services (18 international and 
40 national)  will  be  required.  The  proposed  international  experts  will  include  a  team 
leader/economist,  an  institutional  and  water  users  association  development  specialist,  an 
irrigation and drainage engineer, a land improvement specialist, an environment specialist, a 
social development specialist, a financial and economic analyst, and others, as needed. The 
proposed national experts will include a deputy team leader/irrigation and drainage engineer, an 
irrigation and drainage engineer, an economist, an institutional specialist, an agronomist, a 
sustainable land management specialist, a rural sociologist, an environment specialist, and 
others, as needed. Outline terms of reference for the consultants are presented in Appendix 4. It 
is expected that the consultants will be hired as individuals according to the Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time).  
 
24.  Detailed  terms  of  reference  have  also  been  prepared  for  each  consulting  position 
(Supplementary Appendix).
